coredata.dc:title: X-ray diffraction study on A NiBr2 aqueous solution. Experimental evidence of the Ni(II)Br contacts
coredata.dc:creator: Caminiti, R.
Cucca, P.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
N1Br2 aqueous solution of concentration 2.0 M has been investigated by X-ray diffraction. The experimental correlation function shows four main peaks, centered at about 2.05, 2.65, 3.20 and 4.10 A. The existence of the peak at 2.65 Å shows the presence in solution of the complex Ni(H2O)5Br+ together with Ni(H2O)2+ 6. For the Br− ion, octahedral coordination is confirmed.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 89, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 June 1982 X-RAY DIFFRACTION STUDY ON A NiBr; AQUEOUS SOLUTION. EXPERIMENTAL EVIDENCE OF THE Ni(ll)Br CONTACTS R.CAMINlTlandP.CUCCA Istitiito di aiimica Fisica c Industriale, Umvcwa di Caglian, V'ui Ospcclatc 72, 09100 Caslian. Italy Received 15 M3rcli 1982. in final form 14 Apnl 1982 NiBtj aqueous solution of conccnualion 2.0 M has been investigated by X-ray diffraction. The e\perinicntal correlation function shows four main pi-jks, centered at about 2.05, 2.65,3.20 and 4.10 A.ThccMslencc of the peak at 2.65 A shows tlic prL'scnic in solution of the complex NKHaO); Br* together with Ni(HiO)^. For the Br~ ion, octahedral coordination is cont'iimctl. 1. Introduction X-ray diffraction techniques have been widely used for structural studies of aqueous ionic solutions and a Large amount of knowledge with respeci to the struc- ture of the liydration shell around ions have been ac- cumulated. These X-ray results have been summarized in review articles (1 —1 j. Recently, increasing attention has been devoted to the structure of concentrated aqueous solutions of divalent metal halldcs. Many studies ha\e been carried out on solutions ofNiCI; by X-ray diffraction (5—8J, neutron diffraytion [9-H], EXAFS [12-14] and NMR[15,16j. As far as the nearest neighbors around the cation are concerned, it was found from neutron diffraction studies [9,10] that Ni2"1' has a coordination sphere of six water molecules, while Fontana et al. [11] suggest- ed thai, at concentrations higher than 1 M, about half of the Ni2"1" ions are ii.volved in NiCl^" complexes. In iwo X-ray diffraction studies [5,6] Cammiti et al. liave confirmed the existence of six Mi-Hi 0 nearest neighbor contacts. At the highest concentra- tion, some outer-sphere Ni-Cl correlation was con- sidered possible as due to packing [6]. This result was confirmed by EXAFS studies [12-14], in which no evidence was found for direct Ni-Cl bonding. In a dif- fraction study on 3 M NiCI; aqueous solution, Magini [7] interpreted X-ray diffraction data suggesting that a;8% of inner-sphere contacts may be Ni^-Cl" direct contacts; this amount increases in the case of solutions with a ratio Cr/Ni2-1- > 2 [8]. Weingartner et al. [15, 16] by NMR studies suggest Ni-Cl"1" and NiBr"1" con- tacts for the solutions ofNid^ and NiBr^. Despite many studies on NiCI; solutions, no dif- fractomeinc study has been carried out on NiBr^ solu- tions. For these solutions the equilibrium constants given in the literature [17,18] indicate some Ni-Br"1" formation. Assuming that the above equilibrium con- stants are also valid for concentrated solutions, it can be calculated that 50-80% of the ion is present in the Ni-Br"*" form in solution. In order to clarify further this problem, we under- took the present analysis on 2 NiBr^ solution; in fact Ni-Br contacts should be evident directly in the ex- perimental correlation function since the bromine ion is heavy in comparison to chloride. Another aim of this study was to get deeper knowledge of the coordi- nation-sphere parameters of the bromine, which has not been exien5ively studied [19-22] compared to chlorine [1-10]. 2. Experimental and data treatment Weighed amount ofNiBra^H^O reagent grade was 110 0 009-2614/82/0000-OOOO/S 02.75 © 1982 North-Holland Volume 89, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 June 1982 dissolved in distilled waier. The metal content was de- termined after ion exchange on a cationic resin (Dowex 50W-X8) by titrating the removed H* ion. The Br~ content was evaluated by argentometnc u- trations. The two methods agreed within less than 1%. The concentration of the solution was 2 M in mckel and the molar salt content, expressed as.*: in the com- position [NiBr^[H70](_^, was equal to 0.0377. The density wasd = 1.358 g cm~3. The temperature of the sample was 24 ± 1°C. The experimental procedure and the data-treat- ment technique used have been described [23,24]. Here we remind the reader that the experimental in- tensity data were used in the evaluation of the so- called correlation function according to sma\ G(r) = 1 + (2ir2por)-1 J ,,(,) sw(sr)ds , (1) smm where r is the interatomic distance, pg is the bulk num- ber density of the solution, s is the usual scattering angle, s^^ and s^^ are the lower and upper limit of the experimental data (0.5 and 16.28 A-', respec- tively). i(s) is the structure function as defined by Pings and Waser [25]: [in irm -1-1 ""•'••-S^l3-.<]"• '2' where f, are the scattering factors corrected for anom- alous dispersion, A", the stoichiometnc coefficients in a structural unit containing m kinds of atoms and ]^ is the intensity in electron units. The values of the/, used were taken from International Tables [26] for Br and Ni atoms. The scattering amplitudes for the water molecule were computed by an analytical ex- pression using the coefficients proposed by Hajdu [27]. 3. Analysis of the results 3,1, Correlation function The experimental structure function s i(s) and the correlation function G(r) are plotted in Figs. 1 and 2 (points). The s i(s) function was corrected for low- frequency contributions leading to spurious peaks in the G(r) function below tel.5 A [28]. An inspection Fig. I.I i(s) structure function obtained from experimental data (.-) and s i(s) siruclurc function obtained from tlic model (——). of (lie C(r) allows tlie first qualitative information to be obtained; in it a first very high peak centered at ^2.05 A and a second one at %3.20 A arc the most prominent features. TIiese peaks are indicative of ion-water interactions: in fact, 3.20 A is the Br~- H^O distance observed in bromide solutions [19—22) and tlie peak at 2.05 A is diagnostic ofNi^-HiO distances, as found in some crystal structures [29,301 and in a great number of nickel aqueous solutions [5-14]. Going to higher r values, a clear large peak is evi- dent at =s4.10 A, which should be ascribed to inter- actions from a second hydraiion shell around the ca- rij;. 2. G(r) correlation function obtained from c<pcrimen«al data (—) and G(r) correlation function obtained from the model structure function. Ill Volume 89. number 2 CHEMICAL PHY51CS LETTERS 11 June 1982 lion as previously found [5—8]; in the same range fall the HiO-H^O irans intenictions inside the cation liydration complex and also H-,O—H-)O cis distances (^-l.S A) inside the anion hydration complex and botli should give further contnbu lions to the peak. The peak at 2.65 A, which does not occur in the chloride solutions should be attributed to Ni—Br m- tonciions wiilun the predicted NKHiOsBr"1" com- plex: llie value or the Ni-Br bonding distance in crystals ofNiBr-^H^O 2(C4HgO:)) [30] is 2.55 A. The nearest-neighbor interactions H^O-H^O be- tween hydration water molecules directly H bonded (wi-v/3 interactions), which fall at ^2.75 A, should give further contributions to this peak. 3.2. Model Quantitative parameters for the species present in solution were obtained by least-squares ruling of a calculated structure funciion (s ((s)caic) with the ex- perimental s i(s} curve. Least-squares refinements of the model parameters were performed by tlie PUTLSR program [31] connected with the generalized least- squares LETAGROP program [32] searching the minimum for the error squares sum The contributions of discrete interactions to the syn- thetic structure function are accounted for by using the Debye formula modified in such a way that a gaussian-like distribution of interatomic distances can be introduced [3], while a uniform distribution of distances is described by the formula used by Narten and Levy [33]. A detailed description of this proce- dure can be found elsewhere [23,24]. In budding up the model, both the literature [5-8,15-22] and the qualitative analysis of the peaks evident in the experi- mental correlation function were taken into account. The three complexes NKH^COJ^NitH^O^Br"1' and Br(H^O)g were introduced allowing a second hydra- tion shell around the cation [5—7]; the "continuum" seen by the canon, aiiion and water molecules was accounted for. The NitH^O)^ complex concentra- tion C) was allowed to vary, but the sum of the two cation complexes was fixed to give a 2 M total nickel concentration. The parameters introduced in the fitting procedure were: (a) Complex Ni(HiO)j"1' m octahedral configura- tion: Ci = concentration of the complex, ''Ni-wi = distance nickel—nearest water molecules, ON,_H,, = mean-square deviation of the preceding distance, (JW i - u i = mean-square deviation of the water-water distances in the complex. The distances are related to the Ni—Wj distance by the geometry of the model. (b) Complex N1(1^0)5 Br1" in octahedral configu- raiion: ''Ni-Br= nickel-bromine distance, o^i.Br= mean-square deviation of the preceding distance. 'Ni-w, > °Ni-wi >"w,-wi= °wi-Br were "ot con' sidered independent parameters and were given the values of complex Ni(H'»0)j'*". (c) Complex B^H^O)^ in octahedral configuration: ''Br-u = distance bromine—nearest water molecules, °Br-v> = mean-square deviation of the preceding dis- tance, ffw_v, = mean-square deviation of the water- water distances in the complex. The distances are re- lated to the Br-w distance by the geometry of the model. (d) Second shell around nickel: 411-v., = distance nickel-second-neighbor water molecules, ONI- w = mean-square deviation of the preceding distance, "Ni-w = number of water molecules arranged in the second hydration shell, »\y = distance between nearest-neighbor and second-neighbor water mole- cules, Oy_. ^ = mean-square deviation of the pre- ceding distance. (e) Three mean radii of discrete structure and their mean-square deviations forNi^—HiO.B^—H^Oand H-.O—l^O pairs weie considered as independent pa- rameters. Besides Ihe abovemenlioned procedure, which is that usually used in the analysis of X-ray diffraction data, a second one was also adopted in this case, sug- gested by the good resolution of the peak at 2.05 A. By back-transformation of this peak, a "Filtered" struc- -05 - b-^^ A A .^ ^ ^ v v ^ ^^sA-'————I————1————1————1————I——— 1 1 . 1 1 1 11 1 I I 1 15 17 Fig. 3. {[s i(s)]F}exp (-) and {[s l(s)]F}calc (——) Partial structure functions for the Ni-HaO pail. 112 Volume 89, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 June 1982 Table 1 Parameter values [r is the distance (A); o is llie mean-square deviation, n is the frequency factor, Ci is the concentration of the complex NitHjOig^Ci is the concentration of the com- plex NitHaOtsBr''') obtained from least-squares rcHnerncnts- Standard deviations arc given in parentheses Intcracnon Parameter '"Nl-Wi 2.065(3) °Ni-Wi 0.112(3) Ni(H,0)r ^Nl-Br 2-62(1) NKH^C^Br4 "Ni-Br 0.09(1) Cl 0-3(1) '•2 = [Niiot - Ci 1 1.7 Br(H20)6 '•Br-w 3.12(1) oBr-w 0-196(4) 'Wi -W2 2-79(2) "Wl -W; 0.086(8) second shell for nickel 'TMi-v.'a .1.01(1) oNi-w; 0.209(5) "Ni-w; 10.9(5) lure function [[s i(s)] r-}e\p is obtained (it is shown in rig. 3, points); it is analyzed by using the modified Debye formula [3] as in constructing the total syn- thetic structure function. The refinement by least squares was made, based on the hypothesis that tilis partial structure function comes out, obviously, from Ni-H^O interactions alone. Three parameters only were used:/-Ni_w = distance nickel-nearest water molecules, ONI-WI = mean-square deviation of the Ni-Wi distance, «Ni-wi = average number of water molecules arranged in the first hydration shell. 3.3. Results Satisfactory agreement between experimental and calculated data was reached with the complete model. It can be seen in fig. 2 where the experimental G{r) (points) is compared with the theoretical G(r) (solid line). The structure function from the best fit is shown in fig. 1 (solid line) together with the experi- mental data (points). The final values of the most sig- nificant parameters are listed in table 1. Also in the case of the second procedure very good agreement between {[s '(s)}^}^ (points) and {[s i'(s)lr}caic (solid line) was reached, as can be seen in fig. 3. The final values of the parameters are reported in table 2 together with the parameters obtained in the first analysis. They are in very good agreement. Table 2 Parameter values [r is the distance (A), o is the mean-square devianon,n is the frequency factor] obtained from least- squares rcruicmcnis. Standard deviations arc given in paren- theses Fust analysis Second analysis TMl-Wi °Nl-ttl "Ni-wi 2.065(3)0.112<3)5.1 2.057(8)O.ll3<3)5.1(1) 4. Discussion and conclusions The qualitative analysis of the G(r) and the quan- titative one have clearly shown the existence of the Ni-Br contacts. This in line with theimodynamic equilibrium constants [17,181 and their predictions of the amount of complexes Conned. The number "NI-M = S-KO obtained analysing only the peak at 2.05 A is comparable with that calculable with the first procedure, "Ni-wi = (6C! + ^l)!2 = 5-15 (c! is the concentration of the N1(^0)5 Br* complex). Also the value H;|JJ_D,.= 6-M^i-wi "^O.^ is in good agreement with that calculable assuming the equilib- rium constants given [16,17] for our concentrated solution. Regarding the NI-W) distances from tables 1 and 2, we can see that the values obtained are in good agreement with those found in solutions of nickel chloride [5-8], nitrate [34] and percliloratc [35]. As far as second-order interactions around Ni2"*" are concerned, it is very hkely that the nearest- neighbor water molecules (w,) are H-bonded to outer water molecules (wi). The parameters describing (lie second coordination shell are very sinuldr to those found in chloride solutions [5—7|. As regards the Br- ion, hexacoordination produced a theoretical function which agrees with the experi- mental one; besides, the value obtained for the amon- water mean distance and the mean-square deviation are very close to tliose already found [19-22J, con- firming that the Br" ion also tends to be surrounded by its own hydration shell. head.ce:title: X-ray diffraction study on A NiBr2 aqueous solution. Experimental evidence of the Ni(II)Br contacts

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Istituto di Chimica Fisica e Industriale, Università di Cagliari, Via Ospedale 72, 09100 Cagliari, Italy

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: N1Br2 aqueous solution of concentration 2.0 M has been investigated by X-ray diffraction. The experimental correlation function shows four main peaks, centered at about 2.05, 2.65, 3.20 and 4.10 A. The existence of the peak at 2.65 Å shows the presence in solution of the complex Ni(H2O)5Br+ together with Ni(H2O)2+ 6. For the Br− ion, octahedral coordination is confirmed.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: X-Ray Diffraction Studies on the Structures of Metal Complexes in Solution, Report of the Department of Electronic Chemistry
